BugPattern.Details:
A pointer which is null on an exception path is dereferenced here.  This will lead to a NullPointerException when the code is executed.  Note that because FindBugs currently does not prune infeasible exception paths, this may be a false warning.

Also note that FindBugs considers the default case of a switch statement to be an exception path, since the default case is often infeasible.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Possible null pointer dereference
BugPattern.LongDescription: Possible null pointer dereference of {2} in {1}
BugPattern.Details: A reference value dereferenced here might be null at runtime.  This may lead to a NullPointerException when the code is executed.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Possible null pointer dereference in method on exception path
BugPattern.LongDescription: Possible null pointer dereference of {2} in {1} on exception path
BugPattern.Details:
A reference value which is null on some exception control path is dereferenced here.  This may lead to a NullPointerException when the code is executed.  Note that because FindBugs currently does not prune infeasible exception paths, this may be a false warning.

Also note that FindBugs considers the default case of a switch statement to be an exception path, since the default case is often infeasible.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Possible null pointer dereference due to return value of called method
BugPattern.LongDescription: Possible null pointer dereference in {1} due to return value of called method
BugPattern.Details: A reference value which is null on some exception control path is dereferenced here.  This may lead to a NullPointerException when the code is executed.  The value may be null because it was return from a method which is known to return possibly-null values.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Non-virtual method call passes null for unconditionally dereferenced parameter
BugPattern.LongDescription: Non-virtual method call in {1} passes null for unconditionally dereferenced parameter of {2}
BugPattern.Details: A possibly-null value is passed to a method which unconditionally dereferences it. This will almost certainly result in a null pointer exception.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Method call passes null for unconditionally dereferenced parameter
BugPattern.LongDescription: Method call in {1} passes null for unconditionally dereferenced parameter of {2}
BugPattern.Details: A possibly-null value is passed at a call site where all known target methods will unconditionally dereference it. This is very likely to result in a null pointer exception.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Method call passes null for unconditionally dereferenced parameter
BugPattern.LongDescription: Method call in {1} passes null for unconditionally dereferenced parameter of {2}
BugPattern.Details: This method call passes a null value to a method which might dereference it unconditionally.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Method call passes null to a parameter declared @NonNull
BugPattern.LongDescription: Method call in {1} passes null to a parameter declared @NonNull of {2}
BugPattern.Details: This method passes a null value as the parameter of a method which has declared that parameter to be @NonNull. (Note that the method with the @NonNull annotation may be in a subclass of the receiver object's class.)

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Method may return null, but is declared @NonNull
BugPattern.LongDescription: Method {1} may return null, but is declared @NonNull
BugPattern.Details: This method may return a null value, but the method (or a superclass method which it overrides) is declared to return @NonNull.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Null value is guaranteed to be dereferenced
BugPattern.LongDescription: {2.name} could be null and is guaranteed to be dereferenced in {1}
BugPattern.Details: There is a statement or branch that if executed guarantees that a value is null at this point, and that value that is guaranteed to be dereferenced (except on forward paths involving runtime exceptions).

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Null value is guaranteed to be dereferenced on exception path
BugPattern.LongDescription: {2.name} could be null and is guaranteed to be dereferenced in {1} on exception path
BugPattern.Details: There is a statement or branch on an exception path that if executed guarantees that a value is null at this point, and that value that is guaranteed to be dereferenced (except on forward paths involving runtime exceptions).

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Static initializer for class creates instance before all static final fields assigned
BugPattern.LongDescription: Static initializer for {0} creates instance before all static final fields assigned
BugPattern.Details: The class's static initializer creates an instance of the class before all of the static final fields are assigned.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Method may fail to close stream
BugPattern.LongDescription: {1} may fail to close stream
BugPattern.Details: The method creates an IO stream object, does not assign it to any fields, pass it to other methods, or return it, and does not appear to close the stream on all paths out of the method.  This may result in a file descriptor leak.  It is generally a good idea to use a finally block to ensure that streams are closed.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Method may fail to close stream on exception
BugPattern.LongDescription: {1} may fail to close stream on exception
BugPattern.Details: The method creates an IO stream object, does not assign it to any fields, pass it to other methods, or return it, and does not appear to close it on all possible exception paths out of the method.  This may result in a file descriptor leak.  It is generally a good idea to use a finally block to ensure that streams are closed.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Consider returning a zero length array rather than null
BugPattern.LongDescription: Should {1} return a zero length array rather than null?
BugPattern.Details:
It is often a better design to return a length zero array rather than a null reference to indicate that there are no results (i.e., an empty list of results). This way, no explicit check for null is needed by clients of the method.

On the other hand, using null to indicate "there is no answer to this question", then it is probably appropriate. For example, File.listFiles() returns an empty list if given a directory containing no files, and returns null if the file is not a directory.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Useless control flow
BugPattern.LongDescription: Useless control flow in {1}
BugPattern.Details:
This method contains a useless control flow statement.  Often, this is caused by inadvertently using an empty statement as the body of an if statement, e.g.:

    if (argv.length == 1);
        System.out.println("Hello, " + argv[0]);

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Nullcheck of value previously dereferenced
BugPattern.LongDescription: Nullcheck of {2} at {4.lineNumber} of value previously dereferenced
BugPattern.Details: A value is checked here to see whether it is null, but this value can't be null because it was previously dereferenced and if it were null a null pointer exception would have occurred at the earlier dereference. Essentially, this code and the previous dereference disagree as to whether this value is allowed to be null. Either the check is redundant or the previous dereference is erroneous.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Redundant nullcheck of value known to be null
BugPattern.LongDescription: Redundant nullcheck of {2} which is known to be null in {1}
BugPattern.Details: This method contains a redundant check of a known null value against the constant null.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Redundant nullcheck of value known to be non-null
BugPattern.LongDescription: Redundant nullcheck of {2}, which is known to be non-null in {1}
BugPattern.Details: This method contains a redundant check of a known non-null value against the constant null.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Redundant comparison of two null values
BugPattern.LongDescription: Redundant comparison of two null values {1}
BugPattern.Details: This method contains a redundant comparison of two references known to both be definitely null.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Redundant comparison of non-null value to null
BugPattern.LongDescription: Redundant comparison of non-null value to null in {1}
BugPattern.Details: This method contains a reference known to be non-null with another reference known to be null.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Redundant comparison to null of previously checked value
BugPattern.LongDescription: Redundant comparison to null of previously checked {2} in {1}
BugPattern.Details:
This method contains a redundant comparison of a reference value to null. Two types of redundant comparison are reported:

  • Both values compared are definitely null
  • One value is definitely null and the other is definitely not null

This particular warning generally indicates that a value known not to be null was checked against null. While the check is not necessary, it may simply be a case of defensive programming.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Method does not release lock on all paths
BugPattern.LongDescription: {1} does not release lock on all paths
BugPattern.Details:
This method acquires a JSR-166 (java.util.concurrent) lock, but does not release it on all paths out of the method. In general, the correct idiom for using a JSR-166 lock is: 

    Lock l = ...;
    l.lock();
    try {
        // do something
    } finally {
        l.unlock();
    }

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Method does not release lock on all exception paths
BugPattern.LongDescription: {1} does not release lock on all exception paths
BugPattern.Details:
This method acquires a JSR-166 (java.util.concurrent) lock, but does not release it on all exception paths out of the method. In general, the correct idiom for using a JSR-166 lock is: 

    Lock l = ...;
    l.lock();
    try {
        // do something
    } finally {
        l.unlock();
    }

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Suspicious reference comparison
BugPattern.LongDescription: Suspicious comparison of {3} references in {1}
BugPattern.Details: This method compares two reference values using the == or != operator, where the correct way to compare instances of this type is generally with the equals() method. Examples of classes which should generally not be compared by reference are java.lang.Integer, java.lang.Float, etc.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Call to equals() comparing different types
BugPattern.LongDescription: Call to equals() comparing different types in {1}
BugPattern.Details: This method calls equals(Object) on two references of different class types with no common subclasses. Therefore, the objects being compared are unlikely to be members of the same class at runtime (unless some application classes were not analyzed, or dynamic class loading can occur at runtime). According to the contract of equals(), objects of different classes should always compare as unequal; therefore, according to the contract defined by java.lang.Object.equals(Object), the result of this comparison will always be false at runtime.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Call to equals() comparing different interface types
BugPattern.LongDescription: Call to equals() comparing different interface types in {1}
BugPattern.Details: This method calls equals(Object) on two references of unrelated interface types, where neither is a subtype of the other, and there are no known non-abstract classes which implement both interfaces. Therefore, the objects being compared are unlikely to be members of the same class at runtime (unless some application classes were not analyzed, or dynamic class loading can occur at runtime). According to the contract of equals(), objects of different classes should always compare as unequal; therefore, according to the contract defined by java.lang.Object.equals(Object), the result of this comparison will always be false at runtime.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Call to equals() comparing unrelated class and interface
BugPattern.LongDescription: Call to equals() comparing unrelated class and interface in {1}
BugPattern.Details: This method calls equals(Object) on two references, one of which is a class and the other an interface, where neither the class nor any of its non-abstract subclasses implement the interface. Therefore, the objects being compared are unlikely to be members of the same class at runtime (unless some application classes were not analyzed, or dynamic class loading can occur at runtime). According to the contract of equals(), objects of different classes should always compare as unequal; therefore, according to the contract defined by java.lang.Object.equals(Object), the result of this comparison will always be false at runtime.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Call to equals() with null argument
BugPattern.LongDescription: Call to equals() with null argument in {1}
BugPattern.Details: This method calls equals(Object), passing a null value as the argument. According to the contract of the equals() method, this call should always return false.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Mismatched wait()
BugPattern.LongDescription: Mismatched wait() in {1}
BugPattern.Details: This method calls Object.wait() without obviously holding a lock on the object.  Calling wait() without a lock held will result in an IllegalMonitorStateException being thrown.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Mismatched notify()
BugPattern.LongDescription: Mismatched notify() in {1}
BugPattern.Details: This method calls Object.notify() or Object.notifyAll() without obviously holding a lock on the object.  Calling notify() or notifyAll() without a lock held will result in an IllegalMonitorStateException being thrown.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Self assignment of local variable
BugPattern.LongDescription: Self assignment of local variable in {1}
BugPattern.Details:
This method contains a self assignment of a local variable; e.g.

  public void foo() {
    int x = 3;
    x = x;
  }

Such assignments are useless, and may indicate a logic error or typo.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Self assignment of field
BugPattern.LongDescription: Self assignment of field {2} in {1}
BugPattern.Details:
This method contains a self assignment of a field; e.g. 

  int x;
  public void foo() {
    x = x;
  }

Such assignments are useless, and may indicate a logic error or typo.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Bad attempt to compute absolute value of signed 32-bit random integer
BugPattern.LongDescription: Bad attempt to compute absolute value of signed 32-bit random integer in {1}
BugPattern.Details: This code generates a random signed integer and then computes the absolute value of that random integer. If the number returned by the random number generator is Integer.MIN_VALUE, then the result will be negative as well (since Math.abs(Integer.MIN_VALUE) == Integer.MIN_VALUE).

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Bad attempt to compute absolute value of signed 32-bit hashcode
BugPattern.LongDescription: Bad attempt to compute absolute value of signed 32-bit hashcode in {1}
BugPattern.Details: This code generates a hashcode and then computes the absolute value of that hashcode. If the hashcode is Integer.MIN_VALUE, then the result will be negative as well (since Math.abs(Integer.MIN_VALUE) == Integer.MIN_VALUE).

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Remainder of 32-bit signed random integer
BugPattern.LongDescription: Remainder of 32-bit signed random integer computed in {1}
BugPattern.Details: This code generates a random signed integer and then computes the remainder of that value modulo another value. Since the random number can be negative, the result of the remainder operation can also be negative. Be sure this is intended, and strongly consider using the Random.nextInt(int) method instead.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Remainder of hashCode could be negative
BugPattern.LongDescription: Remainder of hashCode could be negative in {1}
BugPattern.Details:
This code computes a hashCode, and then computes the remainder of that value modulo another value. Since the hashCode can be negative, the result of the remainder operation can also be negative.

Assuming you want to ensure that the result of your computation is nonnegative, you may need to change your code. If you know the divisor is a power of 2, you can use a bitwise and operator instead (i.e., instead of using x.hashCode()%n, use x.hashCode()&(n-1). This is probably faster than computing the remainer as well. If you dont know that the divisor is a power of 2, take the absolute value of the result of the remainer operation (i.e., use Math.abs(x.hashCode()%n)

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Bad comparison of signed byte
BugPattern.LongDescription: Bad comparison of signed byte with {2} in {1}
BugPattern.Details: Signed bytes can only have a value in the range -128 to 127. Comparing a signed byte with a value outside that range is vacuous and likely to be incorrect. To convert a signed byte b to an unsigned value in the range 0..255, use 0xff & b

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Vacuous comparison of integer value
BugPattern.LongDescription: Vacuous comparison of integer value {1}
BugPattern.Details: There is an integer comparison that always returns the same value (e.g., x <= Integer.MAX_VALUE).

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Integer remainder modulo 1
BugPattern.LongDescription: Integer remainder modulo 1 computed in {1}
BugPattern.Details: Any expression (exp % 1) is guaranteed to always return zero. Did you mean (exp & 1) or (exp % 2) instead?

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Bitwise OR of signed byte value
BugPattern.LongDescription: Bitwise OR of signed byte value computed in {1}
BugPattern.Details: Loads a value from a byte array and performs a bitwise OR with that value. Values loaded from byte arrays are signed bytes, and thus this may not give the desired results.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Incompatible bit masks
BugPattern.LongDescription: Incompatible bit masks yield a constant result in {1}
BugPattern.Details: This method compares an expression of the form (a & C) to D, which will always compare unequal due to the specific values of constants C and D. This may indicate a logic error or typo.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Incompatible bit masks
BugPattern.LongDescription: Incompatible bit masks yield a constant result in {1}
BugPattern.Details: This method compares an expression of the form (a & 0) to 0, which will always compare equal. This may indicate a logic error or typo.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Incompatible bit masks
BugPattern.LongDescription: Incompatible bit masks yield a constant result in {1}
BugPattern.Details:
This method compares an expression of the form (a | C) to D. which will always compare unequal due to the specific values of constants C and D. This may indicate a logic error or typo.

Typically, this bug occurs because the code wants to perform a membership test in a bit set, but uses the bitwise OR operator ("|") instead of bitwise AND ("&").

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Incorrect lazy initialization of instance field
BugPattern.LongDescription: Incorrect lazy initialization of instance field {2} in {1}
BugPattern.Details: This method contains an unsynchronized lazy initialization of a non-volatile field. Because the compiler or processor may reorder instructions, threads are not guaranteed to see a completely initialized object, if the method can be called by multiple threads. You can make the field volatile to correct the problem. For more information, see the Java Memory Model web site.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Incorrect lazy initialization of static field
BugPattern.LongDescription: Incorrect lazy initialization of static field {2} in {1}
BugPattern.Details: This method contains an unsynchronized lazy initialization of a non-volatile static field. Because the compiler or processor may reorder instructions, threads are not guaranteed to see a completely initialized object, if the method can be called by multiple threads. You can make the field volatile to correct the problem. For more information, see the Java Memory Model web site.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Synchronization performed on java.util.concurrent Lock
BugPattern.LongDescription: Synchronization performed on java.util.concurrent Lock in method {1}
BugPattern.Details: This method performs synchronization on an implementation of java.util.concurrent.locks.Lock. You should use the lock() and unlock() methods instead.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Private method is never called
BugPattern.LongDescription: Private method {1} is never called
BugPattern.Details: This private method is never called. Although it is possible that the method will be invoked through reflection, it is more likely that the method is never used, and should be removed.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Uncallable method defined in anonymous class
BugPattern.LongDescription: Uncallable method {1} defined in anonymous class
BugPattern.Details: This anonymous class defined a method that is not directly invoked and does not override a method in a superclass. Since methods in other classes cannot directly invoke methods declared in an anonymous class, it seems that this method is uncallable. The method might simply be dead code, but it is also possible that the method is intended to override a method declared in a superclass, and due to an type or other error does not, in fact, override the method it is intended to.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Method may fail to close database resource
BugPattern.LongDescription: {1} may fail to close database resource
BugPattern.Details: The method creates a database resource (such as a database connection or row set), does not assign it to any fields, pass it to other methods, or return it, and does not appear to close the object on all paths out of the method.  Failure to close database resources on all paths out of a method may result in poor performance, and could cause the application to have problems communicating with the database.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Method may fail to close database resource on exception
BugPattern.LongDescription: {1} may fail to close database resource on exception
BugPattern.Details: The method creates a database resource (such as a database connection or row set), does not assign it to any fields, pass it to other methods, or return it, and does not appear to close the object on all exception paths out of the method.  Failure to close database resources on all paths out of a method may result in poor performance, and could cause the application to have problems communicating with the database.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Method concatenates strings using + in a loop
BugPattern.LongDescription: Method {1} concatenates strings using + in a loop
BugPattern.Details:
The method seems to be building a String using concatenation in a loop. In each iteration, the String is converted to a StringBuffer/StringBuilder, appended to, and converted back to a String. This can lead to a cost quadratic in the number of iterations, as the growing string is recopied in each iteration.

Better performance can be obtained by using a StringBuffer (or StringBuilder in Java 1.5) explicitly.

For example:

  // This is bad
  String s = "";
  for (int i = 0; i < field.length; ++i) {
    s = s + field[i];
  }

  // This is better
  StringBuffer buf = new StringBuffer();
  for (int i = 0; i < field.length; ++i) {
    buf.append(field[i]);
  }
  String s = buf.toString();

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Method uses toArray() with zero-length array argument
BugPattern.LongDescription: Method {1} uses Collection.toArray() with zero-length array argument
BugPattern.Details: This method uses the toArray() method of a collection derived class, and passes in a zero-length prototype array argument. It is more efficient to use myCollection.toArray(new Foo[myCollection.size()]) If the array passed in is big enough to store all of the elements of the collection, then it is populated and returned directly. This avoids the need to create a second array (by reflection) to return as the result.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: TestCase implements setUp but doesn't call super.setUp()
BugPattern.LongDescription: TestCase {0} implements setUp but doesn't call super.setUp()
BugPattern.Details: Class is a JUnit TestCase and implements the setUp method. The setUp method should call super.setUp(), but doesn't.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: TestCase implements tearDown but doesn't call super.tearDown()
BugPattern.LongDescription: TestCase {0} implements tearDown but doesn't call super.tearDown()
BugPattern.Details: Class is a JUnit TestCase and implements the tearDown method. The tearDown method should call super.tearDown(), but doesn't.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: TestCase implements a suite method, but this method is not static and should be
BugPattern.LongDescription: TestCase {0} implements a suite method, but this method is not static and should be
BugPattern.Details: Class is a JUnit TestCase and implements the suite() method. The suite method should be declared as being static, but isn't.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: TestCase has no tests
BugPattern.LongDescription: TestCase {0} has no tests
BugPattern.Details: Class is a JUnit TestCase but has not implemented any test methods

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Class overrides a method implemented in super class Adapter wrongly
BugPattern.LongDescription: Class {0} overrides a method {1} implemented in super class Adapter wrongly
BugPattern.Details: This method overrides a method found in a parent class, where that class is an Adapter that implements a listener defined in the java.awt.event or javax.swing.event package. As a result, this method will not get called when the event occurs.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Method attempts to access a result set field with index 0
BugPattern.LongDescription: Method {1} attempts to access a result set field with index 0
BugPattern.Details: A call to getXXX or updateXXX methods of a result set was made where the field index is 0. As ResultSet fields start at index 1, this is always a mistake.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Method attempts to access a result set field with index 0
BugPattern.LongDescription: Method {1} attempts to access a result set field with index 0
BugPattern.Details: A call to getXXX or updateXXX methods of a result set was made where the field index is 0. As ResultSet fields start at index 1, this is always a mistake.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Method attempts to access a prepared statement parameter with index 0
BugPattern.LongDescription: Method {1} attempts to access a prepared statement parameter with index 0
BugPattern.Details: A call to a setXXX method of a prepared statement was made where the parameter index is 0. As parameter indexes start at index 1, this is always a mistake.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Unnecessary type check done using instanceof operator
BugPattern.LongDescription: Method {1} does an unnecessary type check using instanceof operator when it can be determined statically
BugPattern.Details: Type check performed using the instanceof operator where it can be statically determined whether the object is of the type requested.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Bad Applet Constructor relies on uninitialized AppletStub
BugPattern.LongDescription: Bad Applet Constructor relies on uninitialized AppletStub
BugPattern.Details: This constructor calls methods in the parent Applet that rely on the AppletStub. Since the AppletStub isn't initialized until the init() method of this applet is called, these methods will not perform correctly.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: equals() used to compare array and nonarray
BugPattern.LongDescription: {1} uses equals to compare an array and nonarray
BugPattern.Details: This method invokes the .equals(Object o) to compare an array and a reference that doesn't seem to be an array. If things being compared are of different types, they are guaranteed to be unequal and the comparison is almost certainly an error. Even if they are both arrays, the equals method on arrays only determines of the two arrays are the same object. To compare the contents of the arrays, use java.util.Arrays.equals(Object[], Object[]).

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Invocation of equals() on an array, which is equivalent to ==
BugPattern.LongDescription: {1} invokes equals() on an array, which is equivalent to ==
BugPattern.Details: This method invokes the .equals(Object o) method on an array. Since arrays do not override the equals method of Object, calling equals on an array is the same as comparing their addresses. To compare the contents of the arrays, use java.util.Arrays.equals(Object[], Object[]).

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Calls to equals on a final class that doesn't override Object's version
BugPattern.LongDescription: Calls to equals on a final class that doesn't override Object's version
BugPattern.Details:
This method invokes the .equals(Object o) method on a final class that doesn't override the equals method in the Object class, effectively making the equals method test for sameness, like ==. It is good to use the .equals method, but you should consider adding an .equals method in this class.

[Bill Pugh]: Sorry, but I strongly disagree that this should be a warning, and I think your code is just fine. Users of your code shouldn't care how you've implemented equals(), and they should never depend on == to compare instances, since that bypasses the libraries ability to control how objects are compared.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Unneeded use of currentThread() call, to call interrupted()
BugPattern.LongDescription: Method {1} makes an unneeded call to currentThread() just to call interrupted()
BugPattern.Details: This method invokes the Thread.currentThread() call, just to call the interrupted() method. As interrupted() is a static method, is more simple and clear to use Thread.interrupted().

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Static Thread.interrupted() method is mistakenly attempted to be called on an arbitrary Thread object
BugPattern.LongDescription: Method {1} makes a call to the static Thread.interrupted() method, mistakenly attempting to call it on an arbitrary Thread object
BugPattern.Details: This method invokes the Thread.interrupted() method on a Thread object that appears to be a Thread object that is not the current thread. As the interrupted() method is static, the interrupted method will be called on a different object than the one the author intended.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: A parameter is dead upon entry to a method but overwritten
BugPattern.LongDescription: The parameter {2} to {1} is dead upon entry but overwritten
BugPattern.Details: The initial value of this parameter is ignored, and the parameter is overwritten here. This often indicates a mistaken belief that the write to the parameter will be conveyed back to the caller.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Dead store to local variable
BugPattern.LongDescription: Dead store to {2} in method {1}
BugPattern.Details:
This instruction assigns a value to a local variable, but the value is not read by any subsequent instruction. Often, this indicates an error, because the value computed is never used.

Note that Sun's javac compiler often generates dead stores for final local variables. Because FindBugs is a bytecode-based tool, there is no easy way to eliminate these false positives.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Dead store of null to local variable
BugPattern.LongDescription: Dead store of null to {2} in method {1}
BugPattern.Details: The code stores null into a local variable, and stored value is not read. This store may have been introduced in assist the garbage collector, but as of Java SE 6.0, this is no longer needed or useful.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Method defines a variable that obscures a field
BugPattern.LongDescription: Method {1} defines a variable that obscures field {2}
BugPattern.Details: This method defines a local variable with the same name as a field in this class or a superclass. This may cause the method to read an uninitialized value from the field, leave the field uninitialized, or both.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Class defines field that masks a superclass field
BugPattern.LongDescription: Field {1} masks field in superclass {2.class}
BugPattern.Details: This class defines a field with the same name as a visible instance field in a superclass. This is confusing, and may indicate an error if methods update or access one of the fields when they wanted the other.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Inefficient use of keySet iterator instead of entrySet iterator
BugPattern.LongDescription: Method {1} makes inefficient use of keySet iterator instead of entrySet iterator
BugPattern.Details: This method accesses the value of a Map entry, using a key that was retrieved from a keySet iterator. It is more efficient to use an iterator on the entrySet of the map, to avoid the Map.get(key) lookup.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Needless instantiation of class that only supplies static methods
BugPattern.LongDescription: Method {1} needlessly instantiates a class that only supplies static methods
BugPattern.Details: This class allocates an object that is based on a class that only supplies static methods. This object does not need to be created, just access the static methods directly using the class name as a qualifier.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: java.lang.Exception is caught when Exception is not thrown
BugPattern.LongDescription: Method {1} catches Exception, but Exception is not thrown in the try block and RuntimeException is not explicitly caught
BugPattern.Details: This method uses a try-catch block that catches Exception objects, but Exception is not thrown within the try block, and RuntimeException is not explicitly caught. It is a common bug pattern to say try { ... } catch (Exception e) { something } as a shorthand for catching a number of types of exception each of whose catch blocks is identical, but this construct also accidentally catches RuntimeException as well, masking potential bugs.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Doomed test for equality to NaN.
BugPattern.LongDescription: Doomed test for equality to NaN in {1}.
BugPattern.Details: This code checks to see if a floating point value is equal to the special Not A Number value (e.g., if (x == Double.NaN)). However, because of the special semantics of NaN, no value is equal to Nan, including NaN. Thus, x == Double.NaN always evaluates to false. To check to see if a value contained in x is the special Not A Number value, use Double.isNaN(x) (or Float.isNaN(x) if x is floating point precision).

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Test for floating point equality.
BugPattern.LongDescription: Test for floating point equality in {1}.
BugPattern.Details: This operation compares two floating point values for equality. Because floating point calculations may involve rounding, calculated float and double values may not be accurate. For values that must be precise, such as monetary values, consider using a fixed-precision type such as BigDecimal. For values that need not be precise, consider comparing for equality within some range, for example: if ( Math.abs(x - y) < .0000001 ). See the Java Language Specification, section 4.2.4.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Method calls static Math class method on a constant value
BugPattern.LongDescription: Method calls static Math class method on a constant value
BugPattern.Details:
This method uses a static method from java.lang.Math on a constant value. This method's result in this case, can be determined statically, and is faster and sometimes more accurate to just use the constant. Methods detected are:

Method Parameter
abs -any-
acos 0.0 or 1.0
asin 0.0 or 1.0
atan 0.0 or 1.0
atan2 0.0
cbrt 0.0 or 1.0
ceil -any-
cos 0.0
cosh 0.0
exp 0.0 or 1.0
expm1 0.0
floor -any-
log 0.0 or 1.0
log10 0.0 or 1.0
rint -any-
round -any-
sin 0.0
sinh 0.0
sqrt 0.0 or 1.0
tan 0.0
tanh 0.0
toDegrees 0.0 or 1.0
toRadians 0.0

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Test for circular dependencies among classes.
BugPattern.LongDescription: Class {0} has a circular dependency with other classes.
BugPattern.Details: This class has a circular dependency with other classes. This makes building these classes difficult, as each is dependent on the other to build correctly. Consider using interfaces to break the hard dependency.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Class implements same interface as superclass.
BugPattern.LongDescription: Class {0} implements same interface as superclass.
BugPattern.Details: This class declares that it implements an interface that is also implemented by a superclass. This is redundant, once a superclass implements an interface, all subclasses by default also implement this interface. It may point out that the inheritance hierarchy has changed since this class was created, and consideration should be taken into account for the ownership of the interface's implementation.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Class extends Struts Action class and uses instance variables.
BugPattern.LongDescription: Class {0} extends Struts Action class and uses instance variables.
BugPattern.Details: This class extends from a Struts Action class, and uses a instance member variable. Since only one instance of a struts Action class is created by the Struts framework, and used in a multithreaded way, this paradigm is highly discouraged and most likely problematic. Consider only using method local variables.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Class extends Servlet class and uses instance variables.
BugPattern.LongDescription: Class {0} extends Servlet class and uses instance variables.
BugPattern.Details: This class extends from a Servlet class, and uses a instance member variable. Since only one instance of a Servlet class is created by the J2EE framework, and used in a multithreaded way, this paradigm is highly discouraged and most likely problematic. Consider only using method local variables.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Class exposes synchronization and semaphores in its public interface.
BugPattern.LongDescription: Class {0} exposes synchronization and semaphores in its public interface.
BugPattern.Details: This class uses synchronization along with wait(), notify() or notifyAll() on itself (the this reference). Client classes that use this class, may, in addition, use an instance of this class as a synchronizing object. Because two classes are using the same object for synchronization, Multithread correctness is suspect. You should not synchronize nor call semaphore methods on a public reference. Consider using a internal private member variable to control synchronization.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Result of integer multiplication cast to long
BugPattern.LongDescription: Result of integer multiplication cast to long in {1}
BugPattern.Details:
This code performs integer multiply and then converts the result to a long, as in: 

 
	long convertDaysToMilliseconds(int days) { return 1000*3600*24*days; }
If the multiplication is done using long arithmetic, you can avoid the possibility that the result will overflow. For example, you could fix the above code to: 
 
	long convertDaysToMilliseconds(int days) { return 1000L*3600*24*days; }
or 
 
	static final long MILLISECONDS_PER_DAY = 24L*3600*1000;
	long convertDaysToMilliseconds(int days) { return days * MILLISECONDS_PER_DAY; }

BugPattern.ShortDescription: int value cast to float and then passed to Math.round
BugPattern.LongDescription: int value cast to float and then passed to Math.round in {1}
BugPattern.Details: This code converts an int value to a float precision floating point number and then passing the result to the Math.round() function, which returns the int/long closest to the argument. This operation should always be a no-op, since the converting an integer to a float should give a number with no fractional part. It is likely that the operation that generated the value to be passed to Math.round was intended to be performed using floating point arithmetic.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: int value cast to double and then passed to Math.ceil
BugPattern.LongDescription: int value cast to double and then passed to Math.ceil in {1}
BugPattern.Details: This code converts an int value to a double precision floating point number and then passing the result to the Math.ceil() function, which rounds a double to the next higher integer value. This operation should always be a no-op, since the converting an integer to a double should give a number with no fractional part. It is likely that the operation that generated the value to be passed to Math.ceil was intended to be performed using double precision floating point arithmetic.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: int division result cast to double
BugPattern.LongDescription: int division result cast to double in {1}
BugPattern.Details:
This code casts the result of an integer division operation to double. Doing division on integers loses precision. The fact that the result was cast to double suggests that this precision should have been retained. What was probably meant was to cast one or both of the operands to double before performing the division. Here is an example: 

int x = 2;
int y = 5;
// Wrong: yields result 0.0
double value1 =  x / y;

// Right: yields result 0.4
double value2 =  x / (double) y;

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Store of non serializable object into HttpSession
BugPattern.LongDescription: Store of non serializable {2} into HttpSession in {1}
BugPattern.Details: This code seems to be storing a non-serializable object into an HttpSession. If this session is passivated or migrated, an error will result.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Non serializable object written to ObjectOutput
BugPattern.LongDescription: Non serializable {2} written to ObjectOutput in {1}
BugPattern.Details: This code seems to be passing a non-serializable object to the ObjectOutput.writeObject method. If the object is, indeed, non-serializable, an error will result.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Primitive array passed to function expecting a variable number of object arguments
BugPattern.LongDescription: Primitive array passed to {2} in {1}
BugPattern.Details: This code passes a primitive array to a function that takes a variable number of object arguments. This creates an array of length one to hold the primitive array and passes it to the function.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Equals method should assume anything about the type of its argument
BugPattern.LongDescription: Equals method for {0} assumes the argument is of type {2}
BugPattern.Details: The equals(Object o) method shouldn't make any assumptions about the type of o. It should simply return false if o is not the same type as this.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Questionable cast to abstract collection
BugPattern.LongDescription: Questionable cast from Collection to abstract class {3} in {1}
BugPattern.Details: This code casts a Collection to an abstract collection (such as a Collection). Ensure that you are guaranteed that the object is of the type you are casting to. If all you need is to be able to iterate through a collection, you don't need to cast it to a Set or List.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Impossible cast involving primitive array
BugPattern.LongDescription: Impossible cast involving primitive array in {1}
BugPattern.Details: This cast will always throw a ClassCastException.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Impossible cast
BugPattern.LongDescription: Impossible cast from {2} to class {3} in {1}
BugPattern.Details: This cast will always throw a ClassCastException.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: A known null value is checked to see if it is an instance of a type
BugPattern.LongDescription: A known null value is checked to see if it is an instance of {2} in {1}
BugPattern.Details: This instanceof test will always return false, since the value being checked is guaranteed to be null. Although this is safe, make sure it isn't an indication of some misunderstanding or some other logic error.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: A known null value is checked to see if it is an instance of a type
BugPattern.LongDescription: A known null value is checked to see if it is an instance of {2} in {1}
BugPattern.Details: This instanceof test will always return false, since the value being checked is guaranteed to be null. Although this is safe, make sure it isn't an indication of some misunderstanding or some other logic error.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: instanceof will always return false
BugPattern.LongDescription: instanceof will always return false in {1}, since a {2} can't be a {3}
BugPattern.Details: This instanceof test will always return false. Although this is safe, make sure it isn't an indication of some misunderstanding or some other logic error.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: instanceof will always return true
BugPattern.LongDescription: instanceof will always return true in {1}, since all {2} are instances of {3}
BugPattern.Details: This instanceof test will always return true. Although this is safe, make sure it isn't an indication of some misunderstanding or some other logic error.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Unchecked/unconfirmed cast
BugPattern.LongDescription: Unchecked/unconfirmed cast from {2} to class {3} in {1}
BugPattern.Details: This cast is unchecked, and not all instances of the type casted from can be cast to the type it is being cast to. Ensure that your program logic ensures that this cast will not fail.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Questionable cast to concrete collection
BugPattern.LongDescription: Questionable cast from {2} to concrete class {3} in {1}
BugPattern.Details: This code casts an abstract collection (such as a Collection, List, or Set) to a specific concrete implementation (such as an ArrayList or HashSet). This might not be correct, and it may make your code fragile, since it makes it harder to switch to other concrete implementations at a future point. Unless you have a particular reason to do so, just use the abstract collection class.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: "." used for regular expression
BugPattern.LongDescription: "." used for regular expression in {1}
BugPattern.Details: A String function is being invoked and "." is being passed to a parameter that takes a regular expression as an argument. Is this what you intended? For example s.replaceAll(".", "/") will return a String in which every character has been replaced by a / character.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Invalid syntax for regular expression
BugPattern.LongDescription: Invalid syntax for regular expression in {1}
BugPattern.Details: The code here uses a regular expression that is invalid according to the syntax for regular expressions. This statement will throw a PatternSyntaxException when executed.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Overwritten increment
BugPattern.LongDescription: Overwritten increment in {1}
BugPattern.Details: The code performs an increment operation (e.g., i++) and then immediately overwrites it. For example, i = i++ immediately overwrites the incremented value with the original value.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Unsigned right shift cast to short/byte
BugPattern.LongDescription: Unsigned right shift cast to short/byte in {1}
BugPattern.Details: The code performs an unsigned right shift, whose result is then cast to a short or byte, which discards the upper bits of the result. Since the upper bits are discarded, there may be no difference between a signed and unsigned right shift (depending upon the size of the shift).

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Integer shift by an amount not in the range 0..31
BugPattern.LongDescription: Integer shift by {2} in {1}
BugPattern.Details: The code performs an integer shift by a constant amount outside the range 0..31. The effect of this is to use the lower 5 bits of the integer value to decide how much to shift by. This probably isn't want was expected, and it at least confusing.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Integer multiply of result of integer remainder
BugPattern.LongDescription: Integer multiple of result of integer remainder in {1}
BugPattern.Details: The code multiplies the result of an integer remaining by an integer constant. Be sure you don't have your operator precedence confused. For example i % 60 * 1000 is (i % 60) * 1000, not i % (60 * 1000).

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Invocation of toString on an array
BugPattern.LongDescription: Invocation of toString on an array in {1}
BugPattern.Details: The code invokes toString on an array, which will generate a fairly useless result such as [C@16f0472. Consider using Arrays.toString to convert the array into a readable String that gives the contents of the array. See Programming Puzzlers, chapter 3, puzzle 12.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Computation of average could overflow
BugPattern.LongDescription: Computation of average could overflow in {1}
BugPattern.Details:
The code computes the average of two integers using either division or signed right shift, and then uses the result as the index of an array. If the values being averaged are very large, this can overflow (resulting in the computation of a negative average). Assuming that the result is intended to be nonnegative, you can use an unsigned right shift instead. In other words, rather that using (low+high)/2, use (low+high) >>> 1

This bug exists in many earlier implementations of binary search and merge sort. Martin Buchholz found and fixed it in the JDK libraries, and Joshua Bloch widely publicized the bug pattern.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Check for oddness that won't work for negative numbers
BugPattern.LongDescription: Check for oddness that won't work for negative numbers in {1}
BugPattern.Details: The code uses x % 2 == 1 to check to see if a value is odd, but this won't work for negative numbers (e.g., (-5) % 2 == -1). If this code is intending to check for oddness, consider using x & 1 == 1, or x % 2 != 0.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Code contains a hard coded reference to an absolute pathname
BugPattern.LongDescription: Hard coded reference to an absolute pathname in {1}
BugPattern.Details: This code constructs a File object using a hard coded to an absolute pathname (e.g., new File("/home/dannyc/workspace/j2ee/src/share/com/sun/enterprise/deployment");

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Passes a constant value for a month outside of the expected range of 0..11
BugPattern.LongDescription: {1} passes a bad month value of {2} to {3}
BugPattern.Details: This code passes a constant month value outside the expected range of 0..11 to a method.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Invocation of substring(0), which returns the original value
BugPattern.LongDescription: {1} invokes substring(0), which returns the original value
BugPattern.Details: This code invokes substring(0) on a String, which returns the original value.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: hasNext method invokes next
BugPattern.LongDescription: {1} invokes {3}
BugPattern.Details: The hasNext() method invokes the next() method. This is almost certainly wrong, since the hasNext() method is not supposed to change the state of the iterator, and the next method is supposed to change the state of the iterator.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Method calls Thread.sleep() with a lock held
BugPattern.LongDescription: {1} calls Thread.sleep() with a lock held
BugPattern.Details: This method calls Thread.sleep() with a lock held. This may result in very poor performance and scalability, or a deadlock, since other threads may be waiting to acquire the lock. It is a much better idea to call wait() on the lock, which releases the lock and allows other threads to run.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Method uses the same code for two branches
BugPattern.LongDescription: Method {1} uses the same code for two branches
BugPattern.Details: This method uses the same code to implement two branches of a conditional branch. Check to ensure that this isn't a coding mistake.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Method uses the same code for two switch clauses
BugPattern.LongDescription: Method {1} uses the same code for two switch clauses
BugPattern.Details: This method uses the same code to implement two clauses of a switch statement. This could be a case of duplicate code, but it might also indicate a coding mistake.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Method accesses a private member variable of owning class
BugPattern.LongDescription: Method {1} accesses to a private member variable of owning class
BugPattern.Details: This method of an inner class reads from or writes to a private member variable of the owning class, or calls a private method of the owning class. The compiler must generate a special method to access this private member, causing this to be less efficient. Relaxing the protection of the member variable or method will allow the compiler to treat this as a normal access.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Method directly allocates a specific implementation of xml interfaces
BugPattern.LongDescription: Method {1} directly allocates a specific implementation of xml interfaces
BugPattern.Details:
This method allocates a specific implementation of an xml interface. It is preferable to use the supplied factory classes to create these objects so that the implementation can be changed at runtime. See

  • javax.xml.parsers.DocumentBuilderFactory
  • javax.xml.parsers.SAXParserFactory
  • javax.xml.transform.TransformerFactory
  • org.w3c.dom.Document.createXXXX

for details.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Method superfluously delegates to parent class method
BugPattern.LongDescription: Method {1} superfluously delegates to parent class method
BugPattern.Details: This derived method merely calls the same superclass method passing in the exact parameters received. This method can be removed, as it provides no additional value.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Abstract Method is already defined in implemented interface
BugPattern.LongDescription: Abstract Method {1} is already defined in implemented interface
BugPattern.Details: This abstract method is already defined in an interface that is implemented by this abstract class. This method can be removed, as it provides no additional value.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Class is final but declares protected field
BugPattern.LongDescription: Class {0} is final but declares protected field {1}
BugPattern.Details: This class is declared to be final, but declares fields to be protected. Since the class is final, it can not be derived from, and the use of protected is confusing. The access modifier for the field should be changed to private or public to represent the true use for the field.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Method assigns boolean literal in boolean expression
BugPattern.LongDescription: Method {1} assigns boolean literal in boolean expression
BugPattern.Details: This method assigns a literal boolean value (true or false) to a boolean variable inside an if or while expression. Most probably this was supposed to be a boolean comparison using ==, not an assignment using =.

BugPattern.ShortDescription: Class makes reference to unresolvable class or method
BugPattern.LongDescription: Unresolvable reference to {1} by {0}
BugPattern.Details: This class makes a reference to a class or method that can not be resolved using against the libraries it is being analyzed with.

MessageCollection.BugCode: Testing prototype and incomplete bug pattern
Unsynchronized get method, synchronized set method
Equal objects must have equal hashcodes
Uninitialized read of field in constructor
Serializable class with no Version ID
Class's writeObject() method is synchronized but nothing else is
Method returning array may expose internal representation
Inner class could be made static
Bad use of return value from method
Stream not closed on all paths
Prefer zero length arrays to null to indicate no results
Lock not released on all paths
Suspicious use of non-short-circuit boolean operator
Database resource not closed on all paths
String concatenation in loop using + operator
Bug inspired by Josh Bloch's and Neal Gafter's Programming Puzzlers
